wrote=
:
>
> > I'm wondering how to translate (or transliterate) a
> > 'seventeent=
h son'
> > according to the zokumyo naming order. On Anthony
> > Bryant's s=
ite 
> > Sengokudaimyo.com he explains the naming in order of
> > birth. 
>=
 > He ends with the 'eleventh son' (Juichiro). 
> 
> Well, I'm assuming it =
would follow the same pattern,
> and so would be "juu-shichi-rou" (=8F\=8E=
=B5=98Y). 

Yes. "juu-shichi-rou"(=8F\=8E=B5=98Y).

And "Yoshichiro"(=97^=
=8E=B5=98Y) is more commonly used.
In this case, "Yo"(=97^) means "over 10"=
.
Nasu no Yoichi("=DF=90{=97^=88=EA) who was a famous samurai in the Genpei=
 era
was the 11th son of Nasu Suketaka("=DF=90{=8E`=97=B2).
